Chapter 1
Web Components

Web Components is a new set of standards that we can use to create complex UI widgets and application pieces. One platform for creating Web Components is Polymer, developed by Google.

A Web Component contains elements that contain templates, styles, and logic, all encapsulated in that component. They have four specifications which are:

  • Templates
  • Shadow Dom
  • Custom Elements
  • HTML Imports

1.1 Templates

Templates are fragments of HTML for which the content is not loaded, until you get its content using Javascript without using AJAX, such content can be saved inside the <template> and retrieved later.

 
<template class="superman"> 
    <div class="boomshakalaka"> 
        <p class="title">This is the Superman Component</p> 
    </div> 
</template>

The element is pulled doing something as follows:

 
// NOTE: Using webapck 
require(’./superman.scss’); 
// Load the template in the body 
document.body.innerHTML = require("./superman.html") + document.body.innerHTML; 
 
// Retrieve the markup 
var supermanTemplate = document.querySelector(’.superman’); 
var supermanContent = supermanTemplate.content; 
// Add the img picture 
var supermanPicture = document.createElement(’img’); 
supermanPicture.classList.add(’animated_superman’); 
supermanPicture.src = require("../../assets/img/superman.png"); 
supermanPicture.width = 500; 
supermanContent.querySelector(’.boomshakalaka’).appendChild(supermanPicture); 
// Import it to the document, don’t forget the 2nd argument 
var result = document.importNode(supermanContent, true); 
document.body.appendChild(result);

Of course a component wouldn’t be complete with some styling attached to it:

 
.boomshakalaka { 
  border: 5px solid rgba(200, 0, 0, 0.7); 
  padding: 15px; 
  margin: 15px; 
} 
 
.boomshakalaka .title { 
  font-family: sans-serif; 
}

To pull this we are using webpack. The original image I’m using is 1361x561, but we modify that property on load to get an the following:

1.2 Ways of adding templates

There are essentially four ways of adding templates

1.2.1 Hidden elements

Copy/Pasting it the hardcore way.

<div hidden data−template="superman"> 
    <div> 
        <p>SuperMan Template</p> 
        <img src="assets/img/superman.png" class="animated_superman"/> 
    </div> 
</div>

CONS: The browser loads unnecessary markup, and when pasted it wont load the images, video, audio.

1.2.2 Ajax all the things

CONS: Unnecessary noise. Pulling it by Ajax is downright a bad implementation. Somebody could inject bad code using Cross Site Script.

1.2.3 Use a local script template

<script data−template="superman" type="x−template"> 
    <div> 
        <p>SuperMan Template</p> 
        <img src="assets/img/superman.png" class="animated_superman"/> 
    </div> 
</script>

CONS: Unnecessary noise when working with strings.

1.2.4 Compiled templates

A Template engine handles it and you work with the string.

CONS: Unneceessary noise when working with strings.

1.3 Shadow DOM

The audio, video, a, input are de best examples to describe the functionality provided by the Shaodw DOM. Those elements are web components, and we don’t see the internal implementation of these tags.
